title: Get your prismatic biform fonts here: Scans from ‘Alphabet Thesaurus’ Vol. 3
content:
I got my hands on this book of old Photo-Lettering display faces via interlibrary loan and [posted some scans](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013021714/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/joeclark/sets/72157622456252039/detail/ "Photo-Lettering ‘Alphabet Thesaurus Vol. 3’").

And yes, House Industries fans, [Ed Benguiat’s newlock and interlock fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013021714/http:/www.houseind.com/t/e3d290 "Example at HouseInd.com") very much [are in there](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013021714/http:/www.flickr.com/photos/joeclark/4009389057/in/set-72157622456252039/ "One example from the book"). West Doofus Casual FTW.

| Attachment | Size |
| --- | --- |
| [Newlock-Interlock.jpg](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013021714/http:/typophile.com/files/Newlock-Interlock_0.jpg) | 164.69 KB |
author: joeclark

comments.content:
A great set of pictures. Thanks for showing!

Do you know why this is "Photo-Peignot", rather than 'plain'? Specially drawn for the Photo-Lettering house? At a glance, it seems a bit wider than the digital set I have.

The back cover list sure makes me drool. Must be from childhood memories, as all of these fonts were already deemed 'tacky' when I started typesetting. (Admittedly, it also could be my age.)

Theunis, the settings with designations ending in <cite>n</cite> are normal-width. There are condensed and expanded widths in most settings. If you look just at the <cite>n</cite> width, does it seem wider than the Peignot many of us know and love from the titles of <cite>The Mary Tyler Moore Show</cite>?

—  
Joe Clark  
 [http://joeclark.org/](http://web.archive.org/web/20131013021714/http:/joeclark.org/ "http://joeclark.org/")

Ah yes, I see what you mean: the little scribblings at the left, where the center samples are 'normal'.

Yup -- would love to get an OpenType set of this, with these other sets as 'size' variants -- or perhaps stylistic sets, or titling alternates. Come to think of it, that goes for the entire catalog. When is the next 70s revival due?
